I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Upon request of the Government of Indonesia, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
fielded a fact-finding mission in March 2004 to formulate an advisory technical assistance (TA)1 
for Gender Responsive Public Policy and Administration. The TA will help the Government to 
increase women’s participation in political decision making and improve gender mainstreaming 
in  policies  and  programs  at  the  regional  level.  The  Project  directly  addresses  the  third 
Millennium Development Goal to reduce gender disparities and promote gender equality and 
empowerment  through  gender  sensitive  programs  and  projects  at  the  district  level.  The 
objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, cost and financing arrangements, and terms 
of reference for the TA are based on the understanding reached with the Government during the 
mission. The project framework is included in Appendix 1.      
  
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.   Indonesia has undergone political and social reform since the resignation of President 
Soeharto  in  1998.  This  process  has  been  followed  by  greater  political  participation  and  a 
demand  for  increased  representation  of  women  in  political  decision  making  processes. 
Women’s equal participation in the political life is pivotal to their general advancement and 
democratic governance. The goals of equality and sustainable development cannot be achieved 
unless women’s perspectives are incorporated into, and women participate actively in, decision 
making at all levels. Women’s participation in political decision making is very low.  From 1992 
to 1997, women held only 12%2 of the seats in the national parliament; in 2004, 11.1%. The 
representation of women in local representative bodies (LRBs)3 remains low, as well: 13% after 
the election in 2004.   
 
3.  In February 2003, legislation was passed stating that each participating political party 
may nominate candidates for the national parliament and the local parliament for each electoral 
district, giving consideration to representation of women of at least 30%. However, the law did 
not have a significant impact on women’s representation in national representative bodies or in 
LRBs. Women’s representation remains low because (i) few women are involved in political 
parties, (ii) they lack the confidence and skills to operate in public institutions, and (iii) they lack 
awareness of the advantages of women’s national and local representation.    
 
4.   Gender  equality  does  not  flow  simply  from  increased  participation  of  women  in 
representative bodies. The effectiveness of women’s participation in terms of their ability to 
articulate gender interests and the impact of this on actual resource allocation processes and 
decisions  are  also  critical.  To  increase  the  effectiveness  of  women’s  participation  in 
representative bodies, the gender perspective must be mainstreamed into all areas of public 
administration as well. 
 
5.  The introduction of regional autonomy in 2001 resulted in the devolution of substantial 
authority  and  functions  from  the  central  Government  to  regional  governments.4  Regional 
governments are now responsible for ensuring that gender concerns are mainstreamed into all 
aspects  of  local  administration.  Regional  autonomy  opens  a  window  of  opportunity  for 
meaningful  participation of women and for directly  addressing gender disparities at the local 
level.  However, many barriers remain, including a lack of awareness, knowledge, and political

will of decision makers at the regional level. These factors contribute to the suppression of 
women’s rights and weak follow-up in the implementation of international conventions, such as 
the Convention to End all Forms of Discrimination against Women and the Beijing Platform for 
Action. Regional governments  lack technical capacity to mainstream gender  equity concerns 
into policies and programs.   
  
6.  Within regional governments, women’s empowerment divisions5 (WEDs) are responsible 
for ensuring that gender is integrated into planning and policy development of all sectoral offices 
(dinas).6  The  WEDs  provide  technical  input  and  monitor  and  evaluate  the  gender 
responsiveness of the administration. However, they lack the resources and technical expertise 
to implement this task, leaving sectoral offices without specific and practical support in gender 
mainstreaming. Consequently, approaches addressing gender issues at the district level do not 
focus on gender disparities or their causes (discrimination, subordination, and lack of access to 
resources  and  services).  Very  often,  the  emphasis  is  on  support  of  women’s  “traditional” 
domestic, reproductive, and family welfare responsibilities.7 
 
7.  District administrations lack understanding of some of the basic concepts of gender 
mainstreaming and equality and of how to practically implement gender sensitive policies and 
programs. Four basic elements for gender mainstreaming are missing at district level: (i) sex- 
disaggregated data is not collected to analyze gender gaps; (ii) district administrations, including 
the WEDs, lack skills in gender analysis; (iii) there are no procedures to monitor and report on 
gender mainstreaming; and (iv) there are no accountability mechanisms to ensure that women 
and men receive a reasonable proportion of local governments’ resources.  
 
8.  Previous  ADB  assistance  to  strengthen  gender  mainstreaming  capacity  included  a 
small-scale TA8 to strengthen the capacity of the State Ministry of Women’s Empowerment 
(SMWE)  to  coordinate,  monitor,  and  evaluate  the  Government’s  plans  to  mainstream  the 
concern of gender into all sectoral policies, plans, and programs. Another TA9 was to review and 
compile  data  on  the  sociolegal  status  of  women  in  Indonesia.  ADB  supported  a  TA10  to 
mainstream gender equity concerns into development policies, strategies, program design, and 
implementation at the district level.11 While this TA succeeded in increasing the capacity of 
regional governments to mainstream gender, the impact of the TA was limited to the four 
districts where the TA was implemented. To expand the impact, national-level mechanisms 
should be developed to facilitate gender mainstreaming regionally on a larger scale. The TA will 
help SMWE prepare and adopt a national action plan identifying mechanisms, targets, and 
budget requirements to support gender mainstreaming in regional governments. The national 
action plan will be based  on  the SMWE’s  national gender mainstreaming strategy for 2004–
2009. The preparation and adoption of a national action plan for mainstreaming gender at the 
regional level will be an important instrument for ADB and other funding agencies to coordinate 
their gender interventions more effectively.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The  goal  of  the  TA  is  to  reduce  gender  inequality  and  empower  women  through 
participation and gender mainstreaming. The purpose is to help regional governments increase 
women’s participation in political decision making and improve the gender responsiveness of 
regional policies and programs.12     
 
10.  The TA has three expected outputs. First, the TA aims to increase capacity of women as 
present members or future candidates of LRBs to influence political decision making. The TA 
will provide training and help women to organize and mobilize. Second, the TA will ensure 
increased capacity of district administrations to mainstream gender concerns into design and 
monitoring and evaluation of programs and projects. Third, the TA will, in cooperation with 
SMWE, prepare a national action plan13 specifying approaches, targets, and resources needed 
to support gender mainstreaming into regional policies, programs and projects.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA consists of the following components: (i) capacity building of women as present 
members  or  future  candidates  of  LRBs;  (ii)  capacity  building  of  district  administrations  to 
mainstream gender in design, monitoring, and evaluation of programs and projects; and (iii) 
assistance to the SMWE in preparing and adopting a national action plan based on its existing 
national gender mainstreaming strategy for 2004–2009.     
 
12.  Under the first component, an inventory will be made of women already in LRBs and of 
potential  female  candidates  for  LRBs.  The  women  identified  will  be  included  in  training 
programs.14  The training program for potential candidates will include gender and leadership, 
technical skills for campaigning, presentation, negotiation, and handling media, and gender 
awareness  in  general.  The  training  program  for  existing  members  of  LRBs  will  focus  on 
leadership  training,  participatory  planning,  and  gender  sensitive  policies  and  programs, 
technical issues such as legal support, knowledge of how the legislature works, written and 
unwritten  codes,  and  procedures  and  mechanisms  for  conducting  a  political  agenda.  The 
training material will be drawn from existing material prepared by nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs) and research institutions specialized in the areas of gender and governance.  
 
13.  Existing  women’s  groups  involved  in  politics,  such  as  women’s  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) and caucuses, will be mobilized and organized in each district. The TA 
will help establish networks between these groups and local grass-roots organizations and 
similar groups  to ensure linkages between women in  LRBs and their constituents. The local 
networks will act as advocacy or lobby groups for increasing the number of women in LRBs and 
for implementing gender responsive policies and programs. The local networks will connect to 
the national level, with caucuses and organizations, such as the Parliamentarian Forum on 
Population and Development. Best practices on how female politicians have managed to make 
a difference through legislation will be documented. The local networks will use these best 
practices in their advocacy or lobby work.   
                                                 
12 Three districts will be selected from among the 40 districts where the proposed ADB-supported loan project Local 
Government Finance and Governance Reform Program, will be implemented. The districts will be selected based 
on the following criteria: (i) the existence of a well-established women’s empowerment unit, and (ii) political 
commitment from regional governments to implement the TA. 
13 SMWE will develop a new national action plan in 2005 to replace the one covering 2000–2005.   
14 The TA will develop clear and transparent selection criteria for women to be included in the training activities.

4 
14.  The second component of the TA will increase the capacity of district administrations to 
design,  monitor,  and  evaluate  gender  responsive  projects  and  programs.  This  component 
includes  the  establishment  of  gender-disaggregated  data  collection  from  selected  sectoral 
offices so that locally relevant gender issues can be identified. The data will form the basis of a 
report on gender inequalities in the district, to be submitted by the WEDs regularly to the elected 
head of the local government (bupati) and the LRBs. This component will strengthen the WEDs’ 
ability to apply practical approaches to gender analysis in their daily work. This will include skills 
in  information  collection,  gender  sensitive  regulations,  participatory  planning,  and  gender 
sensitive indicators (particularly with respect to monitoring local development targets and the 
millennium development goals). The training will also include participants from selected sectoral 
offices, especially from the district planning board15 and gender focal points from other sectoral 
offices. Finally, a monitoring mechanism will be established in order to track how sectoral offices 
are mainstreaming gender into their programs.      
 
15.  The TA will implement gender responsive budgeting16 in the project areas. This will 
contribute to effective public spending and good governance by improving the delivery of goods 
and  services  to  women  and  men  in  a  just  and  responsible  manner.  The  TA  will  identify 
modalities to support the proposed ADB-supported loan project, local government finance and 
governance reform program (the reform program). Gender responsive budgeting will support the 
reform  program  by  facilitating  enhanced  transparency,  accountability,  efficiency,  and 
effectiveness in the delivery of basic regional services. An important part of gender responsive 
budgets is enhancing participation of communities in planning and preparing the budget. Village 
workshops will be held in the three districts to increase budget literacy of women, in particular. 
The  TA  will  provide  training  of  relevant  sectoral  offices  (including  the  WEDs)  in  gender 
responsive budgeting. Such budgeting will then be replicated in all the districts where the reform 
program is going to be implemented.   
 
16.  The third component of the TA consists of preparing a national action plan for SMWE. 
The action plan will identify (i) targets for mainstreaming gender at the local level for the next 3 
years,  (ii)  milestones  and  gender  indicators to  monitor  and  evaluate  progress,  (iii)  gender 
capacity-building requirements over the next 3 years for the effective implementation of the 
SMWE’s national gender mainstreaming strategy, and (iv) resources needed to implement the 
national action plan.      
  
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent, comprising $238,000 in 
foreign exchange cost and $262,000 in local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 by the Government of the United Kingdom17 and 
administered by ADB. The Government will provide $100,000 equivalent in the form of office 
and support facilities, counterpart staff, administrative support, part of workshop expenses, and 
local transportation for counterpart staff. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are 
shown in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
18.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be SMWE.  NGOs specializing in women in politics 
will provide training packages and conduct training for women in LRBs and potential women 
candidates.  A  coordination  unit  with  representatives  from  the  WED,  district  development 
planning board, bureau of statistics, and key local representative members will be established in 
each of the three districts to oversee TA implementation. Detailed terms of reference for the 
coordination units will be developed and agreed to at the inception meeting. The project director 
will be identified by SMWE before the commencement of the TA.  The project director, whom 
the SMWE will identify before the TA starts, will provide the overall coordination. The TA 
consultants will be located at SMWE and in the three selected districts.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months from March 2005 to March 2006 and will 
require 40 person-months of consulting services, including 10 person-months for international 
consultants and 24 person-months for domestic consultants engaged by the SMWE through a 
consulting firm. The TA also includes 6 unallocated person-months for recruiting NGOs. The 
consultants will be engaged in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by 
Asian Development Bank and its Borrowers using the quality- and cost-based selection method, 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. All 
procurement under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The 
SMWE will be responsible for providing the agreed counterpart resources. The proposed terms 
of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
20.  The consultants will prepare (i) an inception report, including a detailed work program 
within the first month; (ii) monthly progress reports; (iii) a midterm review report after 7 months; 
(iv) a draft final report; and (v) a final report within 1 month after receiving comments on the draft 
final report. Tripartite review meetings between SMWE, the consultants and the ADB will be 
held after inception and at the draft final report stage. The consultants will also be responsible 
for preparing technical reports as specified in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to the Government 
of Indonesia to be financed on a grant  basis by  the  Government of the United Kingdom for 
Gender Responsive Public Policy and Administration, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction  
 
1.  A team of consultants consisting of one international consultant (10 person-months) and 
three domestic consultants (24 person-months) will be engaged for a total of 34 person-months. 
The team of consultants will be engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through a 
consulting  firm.  Additionally  six  unallocated  domestic  person  months  will  be  allocated  for 
engaging non-government organizations (NGOS) to conduct training activities. 
  
2.  The team leader should have a postgraduate degree in gender studies or relevant social 
science qualifications with experience in gender and development (especially women in politics, 
gender and governance, and gender budgeting); project management; and participatory training 
methodologies. The domestic consultants should have extensive experiences in gender training, 
gender analysis, and gender budgeting. Preferably, one of the consultants should have a legal 
background, or experience in working with gender and legal issues. The consultants should also 
have  knowledge  of  local  government  policies  and  structure  and  experience  in  advocating 
organizational changes with senior government officials.  
    
3.  The  tasks of the consultants will require a proactive and demand-based approach, 
working  in  close  consultation  with  local  governments,  NGOs,  and  other  stakeholders.  The 
consultants will develop the project following a bottom-up approach and a highly consultative 
process.

C.  Reporting Requirements    
 
7.  The consultants will submit the following reports to the EA and ADB: 
 
(i)  Inception report.  A report including a detailed work program will be submitted 
within 1 month after consulting services start, highlighting progress made and 
any recommendations and proposed changes to the TA work program. 
(ii)  Training programs. Based on existing training material on women in politics, 
training  programs  for  each  district  will  be  submitted  after  2.5  months  after 
consulting services start.  
(iii)  Gender analysis of local budget. A report including a gender analysis of the 
local budgets in the three districts, and recommendations on how to mainstream 
gender in local budgets will be submitted 8 months from consulting services start. 
(iv)  Gender profiles for the three districts. 
(v)  Action plans. Plans will specify how gender can be mainstreamed into the 
reform program in the three districts. 
(vi)  National action plan. The plan will specify mechanisms, targets and budget 
requirements  for  SMWE  to  support  gender  mainstreaming  in  regional 
governments.  
(vii)  Monthly  progress  reports.  These  reports  will  assess  progress  and 
implementation.   
(viii)  Midterm  review  report.  A  midterm  report  will  be  submitted  6  months  after 
consulting  services  start.  It  will  assess  overall  progress  and  implementation, 
identify problems and achievements, and propose necessary adjustment to the 
Project.  
(ix)  Draft final report. This report is to be submitted no later than January 2006. 
(x)  Final report. A final report will be prepared after due consideration of comments 
made by the Government and ADB on the draft final report. The final report will 
be presented within 2 weeks of receipt of comments on the draft final report.
